example_quotes: Medical Student: Confusion or memory loss?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: Joint pains or muscle aches?
Patient: I mean sometimes I can get so like my knees will hurt, but I think that's just arthritis.
Medical Student: Uhm, changes in your bowel movement?
Patient: No diarrhea.
Medical Student: How about chest pain?
Patient: Uh, yeah, I've had this kind of like dull kind of aching pain that, that I've had kind of work just on the right side of my chest.
Medical Student: So no blood or sputum?
Patient: Uh no, no blood or sputum.
Medical Student: Confusion or memory loss?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: And how about like blood in your stool or constipation?
Patient: No constipation and no blood in the stool.
Patient: Uh, I've had this cough. It's been going on now for like last six months or so and been losing some weight as well.
Medical Student: Uhm, changes in your bowel movement?
Patient: No diarrhea.
Medical Student: How about shortness, sorry, how about dizziness or fainting spells?
Patient: Nothing like that.
Medical Student: And have you been feeling short of breath at all?
Patient: Uhm, I have, yeah the shortness of breath has been like similarly getting a bit worse over the last, over the last six months.
Medical Student: How about shortness, sorry, how about dizziness or fainting spells?
Patient: Nothing like that.
Medical Student: No. How about fatigue?
Patient: Not really, no.
Medical Student: Any fevers?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: How about headaches?
Patient: No headaches.
Medical Student: Changes in your vision or hearing?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: So no blood or sputum?
Patient: Uh no, no blood or sputum.
Medical Student: Uhm, appetite changes?
Patient: No way my appetite's been been OK, that's why I was like really shocked at the the weight loss.
Medical Student: Runny nose or stuffy nose?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: OK, nausea or vomiting?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: How about chest pain?
Patient: Uh, yeah, I've had this kind of like dull kind of aching pain
Medical Student: And do you ever feel like your heart's racing?
Patient: No, I haven't had any anything like that. I mean like, sometimes I can get palpitations 'cause I have a fib or atrial fibrillation, but it doesn't really yeah, affect me that, that much.
Medical Student: And how about like blood in your stool
Patient: No constipation and no blood in the stool.
Medical Student: Runny nose or stuffy nose?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: Smell or taste?
Patient: That's been normal.
Medical Student: Sore throat?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: Smell or taste?
Patient: That's been normal.
Patient: Uh, I've had this cough. It's been going on now for like last six months or so and been losing some weight as well. I've lost, I think like 20 or 30 pounds in the last six months.
Medical Student: Uhm, how about changes in your urine?
Patient: No, I mean sometimes I can have a, I mean harder time to go 'cause as an old guy have large prostate I think they said, but I mean that's been OK.
Medical Student: Changes in your vision or hearing?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: OK, nausea or vomiting?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: OK. Alright, and is there wheeziness as well?
Patient: No wheezing.
